title: Killer cold to blitz UK: Met Office alert on -18C blast
text:
The weather phenomenon, Sudden Stratospheric Warming, has not occurred for four years. 
It usually brings freezing temperatures and can result in heavy snow for many areas. 
The conditions occur when the North Pole’s high-altitude air suddenly warms up and shunts cold low-level Arctic air south to Britain. The arctic freeze across Europe: and its on its way HERE! Monday, 9th January 2017 Europe is in the grip of an icy, arctic freeze. With snowfall in Italy, Greece and Turkey, we're expecting the snow to fall in Britain soon. 1 / 13 Getty Images A man walks on snow covered road during heavy snowfall in Istanbul. “These events disrupt the stratospheric polar vortex and, more often than not, bring cold weather to the UK” Met Office 
Met Office experts are warning of a possible Arctic blast in their February to April forecast. 
They noted: “These events disrupt the stratospheric polar vortex and, more often than not, bring cold weather to the UK.” 
The Met Office’s Professor Adam Scaife said: “Sudden Stratospheric Warming involves a complete reversal of the high altitude polar jet stream. 
GETTY BRRRR..: The cold snap is set to last for three weeks 
“This can burrow into the lower stratosphere. 
“The Atlantic jet stream often weakens and moves south. 
“This allows cold air from the east into northern Europe and the UK.” 
Colder and drier conditions are predicted by the Met Office from the end of next weekend for up to three weeks. 
GETTY ARCTIC COLD: The bitter condition will be caused by a rare North Pole phenomenom 
Britain was last hit by a SSW in 2013 when we had the coldest March for 51 years, with snow and a -12.5C low in Braemar, Aberdeenshire. 
The phenomenon also triggered -18C lows in Powys, Wales, in November 2010 – starting a monthlong freeze – and -18.4C temperatures in the Scottish Highlands in February 2009. 
Meanwhile, cold easterly winds from Russia dubbed ‘the Beast from the East’ will arrive on Wednesday and last until the end of the week. 
GETTY FREEZING: Eastern England will bear the brunt of the cold weather 
Temperatures could fall as low as -4C – colder than parts of Greenland – with a possibility of snow. 
Met Office forecaster Mark Wilson said: “The winds’ original source is Russia. 
“There is potential for the cold to reach the West later in the week, with perhaps snow on high ground. It looks like staying colder than average.” 
Last night, the Met Office warned western Britain could face a week’s rain tomorrow. Related articles
